Issues.Title: fix(core): deduplicate imports of standalone components in JIT compiler
Issues.Body:
During JIT compilation of standalone components the compiler did not deduplicate
declarations in the imports array, unlike the AOT compiler. This may result in
runtime errors during directive matching, when the same component is found
multiple times resulting in NG0300, for example:

> NG0300: Multiple components match node with tagname mat-form-field: MatFormField and MatFormField.

This commit fixes the issue by deduplicating imports in the JIT compiler.

Relates to https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/46109#issuecomment-1160705031

Closes #46109

Issues.Title: Add more validator in `Validators`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

forms

### Description

I am really wondered why we should have `Validators` in the `@angular/forms` while it has less than satisfactory proficiency as I can measure by counterpoising it to something like [class-validator](https://github.com/typestack/class-validator). I am not devaluing `Validators`. I am just saying when we finally have to install [3rd party packages](https://openbase.com/categories/js/best-angular-validation-libraries) due to lake of `Validators` functionality why even it should exists?

I am just asking question. If you ask me I would say I prefer to use Angular built-in functionalities if it gave me what I need. BTW this is my opinion and please tell me if I am wrong.

### Proposed solution

Add more built-in validators. here is a simple list which I would say pretty much every developer in his app needs:

- isBoolean
- isAlphanumberic
- isAlpha
- isUppercase
- isLowercase
- validateIf // as its name implies it will validate if a given condition be true. Mostly that condition emerges from the form
- isNumber
- isInt32
- isInt64
- isFloat
- isDouble
- isString
- isDateString
- isDate

I know some of them seems unreasonable but this is my opinion.

I am inspired by class-validator.

### Alternatives considered

There is no problem with publishing uncomplete API where there are plans to make it better - Kaizen.
But if there is no plan to make it better and other libraries did/do not build their libraries on top of it, IMHO it is better to turn it off.

Note: Even though I said and say this is a #completely_personal_opinion. But I feel righteous indignation :joy: just kidding.

Issues.Title: Component Styles are not shared anymore but duplicated per component with Ivy
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

**Use Case**:  
We use Angular Elements to define multiple WebComponents. Each WebComponent uses `ViewEncapsulation.ShadowDom` and includes a SCSS file that provides some "global" (= inside Shadow DOM) classes that can be used by all child components (which use default encapsulation).

**Problem**:  
Multiple Angular Components include the same SCSS file via styleUrls. After building the app, the main bundle now includes these CSS styles once per component, the styles are duplicated - which results in a large bundle (and thus requires to increase the budget limit).

We use Angular 13/14 but the problem can be reproduced in a newly created Angular 11 app. After disabling Ivy (which is not possible in newer Angular versions) the styles are not duplicated anymore but only included once in the bundle and referenced by all components. And that's the behavior I would expect.

I don't know if this change was intended or not but I couldn't find any information about that in the update guide / changelog / PRs.

For components with `ViewEncapsulation.Emulated` styles cannot be (easily) shared because the selectors are made unique but it's possible for Shadow DOM (and `ViewEncapsulation.None` I guess).

https://github.com/rothsandro/repro-angular-duplicated-component-styles

Issues.Title: AbstractControl pristine and dirty properties behaviour
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

@angular/forms

### Description

The properties _pristine_ and _dirty_ should indicate if the value of a FormControl or FormGroup has changed yet, but the behaviour of those properties is not perfectly logical. If you start typing another value into a FormControl the value has changed referenced to the initial value. But if you type the inital value back into the control, the properties remain and that is not logical.
In that case you have only touched the control and the properties _touched_ and _untouched_ are set correctly.

### Proposed solution

_Pristine_ and _dirty_ should be chnaged only when the value of a control is different to it's initial value. Currently pristine and dirty indicate pretty much the same when you have change something in the control, but revert the changes.

### Alternatives considered

Alternatively some additional properties that indicate the behaviour I described would be useful. E.g. for a case when you want to show a save-bar but only when values are different to the initial values.

Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [x] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? This worked in v13 of the CLI ### Description We are working on updating our ng deploy schematic for Angular 14, unfortunately some command line arguments are no longer detected correctly. Arguments like `noBuild`, `noSilent`, `noDotFiles` no longer work, but `buildTarget` and `dryRun` do. I assume this is related with https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/22778 and the fact that Yargs supports `--no-flags`. In the past, the word `no` had no meaning, now it has one: https://github.com/yargs/yargs/blob/main/docs/tricks.md#negate In Angular 13 i was able write `no-build` as an argument and it was used as it-is, but now this is interpreted as the negation of `build` – which is an unknown argument. This breaks a couple of builders that all share some code/ideas and use the same argument called `no-build`. * [@netlify-builder/deploy](https://github.com/ngx-builders/netlify-builder/blob/b915395041d61d460f3a312c1a9c7cc9a683cda2/src/deploy/schema.json#L17) * [angular-cli-ghpages](https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages#no-build) * as well as [ngx-deploy-docker](https://github.com/kauppfbi/ngx-deploy-docker), [ngx-deploy-npm](https://github.com/bikecoders/ngx-deploy-npm), and [ngx-deploy-ftp](https://github.com/bohoffi/ngx-deploy-ftp) * there could be more... ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Please follow our [README for contributors](https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages/blob/master/docs/README_contributors.md), which is essentially: 1. Clone the project ```sh git clone https://github.com/angular-schule/angular-cli-ghpages.git cd angular-cli-ghpages ``` 2. Install the dependencies ```sh cd src npm install ``` 3. Build the project: ```sh npm run build ``` 4. Create a local npm link: ```sh cd dist npm link ``` 5. Go to a new folder and create a fresh angular project: ```sh ng new test cd test ``` 6. Add the local version of `angular-cli-ghpages`. ```sh npm link angular-cli-ghpages ``` 7. Now execute the `ng-add` schematic. ```sh ng add angular-cli-ghpages ``` 6. This will work, but will complain about a missing git configuration (which is fine here) ```sh ng deploy ng deploy --dry-run ``` 6. But this will NOT work, same for all other arguments with a "no" in the name ```sh ng deploy --no-build ``` ## 🔥 Exception or Error 
ng deploy --no-build
Error: Unknown argument: build

Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: Angular 10. ### Description 1. In Angular 13, when I click a dropdown for the Angular Material MatMenu, it will sometimes position the dropdown options underneath the bottom of the page. I can get it to do it reliably by clicking "Refresh" in my browser over and over (it happens roughly 50% of the time so I can usually get the behavior to come out with the 4th refresh or so). 2. When I inspect the css in DevTools, I see that `cdk-overlay-container` does not have the styles like `position: fixed;` that place it in the right location. In other words, the material styles do not seem to have loaded. 3. This bug does **not** occur in development, only when building (`ng build`) or serving in production (`ng serve --configuration production`). Moreover, if I set `optimization: false` within `angular.json` for `production`, the bug also disappears. This is why I am posting this issue within the angular-cli repo as I am guessing that the issue stems from the minification process or something else in the optimization process. 4. In looking around, a lot of other people who have experienced the same Angular Material issue experience it when they do not load the prebuilt themes (e.g. https://github.com/angular/components/issues/1387), but I do have the prebuilt themes loaded correctly (which is why for me it works around 50% of the time, but doesn't work 50% of the time). I was able to find one other case in which others experienced "random" occurrences of missing styles like what I'm experiencing. In that issue (links below), it was found that "Chrome loads styles for Material later then application starts rendering in Angular". So my **guess** is that the bug I'm experiencing is also related to the timing of when styles are being loaded. * https://supportcenter.devexpress.com/ticket/details/t915721/devextreme-material-theme-doesn-t-load-properly-in-production-build * https://supportcenter.devexpress.com/ticket/details/t917577/devextreme-does-not-attach-additional-classes-to-dx-viewport-in-chrome-84-on-the-first Any chance all of those clues mean something to someone? ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction I haven't quite been able to create a simple reproduction in Stackblitz, but I got pretty close with this Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-afy6ka?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.html,src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.css,src%2Fstyles.scss,angular.json. When I first created that stackblitz and started working towards a reproduction, I recreated the problem by just removing the `aot: true` from `angular.json` and adding a simple example of a mat-menu within a page with `height: 100%;` for `html`, `body`, and all containers. However, once I used the "Share" link from the Stackblitz, the problem wasn't there anymore. I created a screen recording to show that I really did create the effect in this Stackblitz, but it somehow disappeared when I Shared it and also after I refreshing the browser https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/863081/174004841-7edb886f-f8dc-4085-8bc5-3dea3fc883c2.mov I'm hoping that the combination of all these clues will give someone an idea of what the issue is. ## 🔥 Exception or Error No exceptions or errors. ## 🌍 Your Environment

### What are you trying to do?

When creating a mat-datepicker component we have the following example:
```html
<mat-datepicker #picker>
  <mat-datepicker-actions *ngIf="prop$ | async">
     ...
  </mat-datepicker-actions>
</mat-datepicker>
```

Within this datepicker's header, there's a mat-slide-toggle that updates the _props$_ state to T/F. However, when updated, the mat-datepicker-actions remain visible within the template...

Is there a way to ensure the actions can be shown/removed without having to close and repoen the datepicker popover?

1. Force change detection via `ChangeDetectorRef`.
2. Utilize the `registerActions` and `removeActions` methods on `MatDatepicker`.

_No response_

### Description

I'm reposting this issue again: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/6466

since you closed it without providing any reasonable workaround or an explanation why you chose to implement this super weird, opinionated, behaviour. What is the reason to implement it like this? What problems does you implementation solve or prevent? From what I can see, it's just limiting a very common use-case, without any reasonable benefits. If you really insist on this, at least make it optional with an input binding, so we can opt-out of it when we don't need it. 

The only workaround for this is to use some other value, e.g. '' and then map it back and forth all over the place, for each mat-select. Honestly this is ridiculous. Totally messy, bug prone etc. and still a very poor workaround.

Issues.Title: bug(MatDatepickerModule): MatDatepicker jumps between Date formats in Input
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When using the MatDatepickerModule and adding a MatDatepicker or MatDateRangePicker, the value in the input jumps between two date format states. 
This seems to only occur when changing the MAT_DATE_LOCAL Injection Token. I only tested this with 'de-DE', so I don't know if this happens with different formats t.o. 
It changes its value when you enter the vanilla HTML Input and do a change that marks the input as touched. So adding a space behind the value also triggers this. The value seems to switch back and forth between dd-MM-yyyy and MM-dd-yyyy. 

This also only occurs if both `MM` and `dd` are valid `MM` candidates. So `31-01-2022` will not jump between formats, while `01-02-2022` does. 

### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-mlmcoc?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Choose a Date from the datepicker that uses a Day which is valid as a month
2. Click into the vanilla HTML Input
3. Press the spacebar or change anything in the value
4. Click outside the input or press tab to loose focus


### Expected Behavior

The value inside the vanilla HTML input should not switch the date-format when touching it and blurring it again. 

### Actual Behavior

The value inside the vanilla HTML input switches back and forth between `dd.MM.yyyy` and `MM.dd.yyyy`

### Environment

- CDK/Material: 14.0.2

13.x

### Description

The interface `OverlayReference` can no longer be imported. This is somewhat unfortunate because the interface is being used as an argument for the `.attach()` method of `PositionStrategy` which is still being exported. The TypeScript compiler with `strict` or `noImplicitAny` refuses to build the application. 

My guess is that this file needs to export the interface https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/cdk/overlay/public-api.ts 

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

### Expected Behavior

Being able to import all required types and interfaces for already exposed interfaces.

### Actual Behavior

The shipped index.d.ts specifies the following:

```
declare interface OverlayReference {
```

which means that TypeScript won't import the interface. That would require the `export` keyword
